# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

```julia
using DataFrames
using CSV # only needed if you plan to read from a csv file

function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    # filter the data for rows with manufacturer "audi" and model "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_audi = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi" && (row[:model] == "a4" || row[:model] == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)

    # add a new column `audi_a4_type` with value `true` across all rows
    df_audi[!, :audi_a4_type] = true 

    return df_audi
end
```
To use this function, simply pass your DataFrame `df_cars` as an argument. If you have a csv file, you can first load it into a DataFrame using `CSV.read`.
```julia
# load the data from a csv file (assuming the file is called "car_data.csv")
df_cars = CSV.read("car_data.csv", DataFrame)

# filter down the dataset to audi a4 and a4 quattro models
df_audi = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
